instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2936: What is 820-2936? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No vcore
threads.message:
Board badly liquid damaged from J9000 to <TRANSISTOR>Q5520</TRANSISTOR>.

Parts replaced, traces repaired.
5V S0 = 5V
3V3 S0 = 3V3
1V05 S0 = 1V05

<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> = missing
<RESISTOR>R7967</RESISTOR> (1) = 3V3 (2) = missing


Any ideas please?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No vcore
threads.message:
Tell us which secondary coils don't get voltage; leave CPU coils for the moment, check the others.
Any one shorted to ground?
Post <TRANSISTOR>Q7950</TRANSISTOR> voltages.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No vcore
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> now  = 1.69V
Still no vcore

No shorts on any chokes
Expected voltages on all other chokes but L7100, L7550, L7510, L7520 = 0V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No vcore
threads.message: Can anyone tell me what <SIGNAL>CPUIMVP_TON</SIGNAL> voltage at pin 2 of <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> should be please?... Currently 0.5V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No vcore
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> still too low, should be 3V.
Strange to have 0.5V at TON, as that is the correct voltage when CPU power supply works...
Get correct <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> first.
